results.title: Rock pools: an introduction
results.creator_credit: Anvil Films and Record Group, Seabourne Enterprises and Donald Walton
results.brief_description: This film is a study of plants and animals whose structure and habits enable them to live in rock pools. The close association between plants and animals is illustrated. The ecology of rock pools is related to the rise and fall of the tide, heating and cooling, desiccation and flooding. Suitable for upper primary and lowere secondary levels.

results.title: Rock engravings
results.brief_description: Aboriginal rock carvings in Western New South Wales are being studied by archaeologists to discover their significance and to throw light on the culture which produced them. The age of the carvings cannot be determined, but many may be thousands of years old.

results.title: Rock bottom at Waikaremoana
results.brief_description: The lake at Waikaremoana is one of the North Island’s major sources of water for hydro-electric power. However, weakness in the bed of the lake has resulted in considerable loss of valuable water. With a full-sized movie camera fitted in his special diving helmet, a cameraman recorded how divers located and sealed these leaks in the lake bed.

results.title: Rock 'n' roll and the 1950's. Vols 5-6. Big beat legends: the evolution of rock on television
results.creator_credit: Video 45, Diamond Productions and Renaissance Theatre Company
results.brief_description: Rock ‘n’ roll and the 1950’s presents volumes 5 and 6 from their collection of rare and historical footage which captures the energy and values of the 1950’s that embodied the Rock & Roll culture. Featured is live performance clips along with movie trailers, advertisements and other footage that describe the mood of the day and it’s cultural values. Volume 5 along with musical performances features footage celebrating the sci-fi film genre and the TV serial. Volume 6 features footage of some of the bombshells that represented changing values on sexuality in the fifties. Included are televised performances of: Jane Mansfield, Lavern Baker, Chuck Berry, Frankie Lyman. Included in this double-feature is documentary “The Big beat legend: the evolution of rock on television”. This documentary looks at Alan Freed, the New York DJ who coined the phrase ‘rock n’ roll’ and played without prejudice the music of both black and white performers equally. Included are: the Exciters, Bill Haley, Fats Domino, The Platters, Frankie Lynman and the Teenagers, Bobby Darin, The Diamonds, Dion, Jerry Lee Lewis and Jackie Wilson.

results.title: Rock-a-bye baby
results.creator_credit: L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World We Live In”.
Examines some of the techniques psychologists use to assess mothering practices with young infants. Stresses the importance of touch and movement in young children. Examples of monkeys in isolation, children in orphanages, and premature infants are used to show the effects of various maternal deprivations. Narrated by Dan Ingram. NB: CONTAINS SOME DISTURBING IMAGES WITH MONKEYS.

results.title: Robots: the animated docu-soap
results.brief_description:
Just another day in the life of three ordinary robots suffering for their art - Jackson, a painter/sculptor; Roland, a composer/musician; and Hands, a champion skater. This award-winning animated film tracks the demise of the three redundant robots as they attempt to reassert meaning into their empty lives. Made in the style of a documentary-soap and containing a rather dark sense of humour, this is a somewhat offbeat satirical depiction of the genre.
Voice: David Hopewell. (Awards: Best New British Animation, Edinburgh International Film Festival 2000; Jury Award, Art Film Festival 2001)

results.title: Robots: computers at work (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Before we consider the impact of robots on our lives, we need to know more about how they work, what they can do, and how scientists and engineers see them developing in the future. This film takes its examples mainly from Japan where more robots are currently in use than in any other country, including U.S.A.

results.title: Robots: computers at work
results.brief_description: In industry robots have taken over work which is dull, dirty, or dangerous. But there are many other applications such as nursing, helping the blind, fighting fires and crime prevention. Before we consider the impact of robots on our lives, we need to know more about how they work, what they can do, and how scientists and engineers see them developing in the future. This film takes its examples mainly from Japan where more robots are currently in use than in any other country.

results.title: Robots for Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
A brief look at the work being carried out by the CSIRO in programming computers to carry out functions in the manufacturing industries. Also raises issues regarding the changing face of the worplace. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
